content: How can I help you today?

Honestly, I'm not even sure where to start. Things have been so overwhelming at home—my son has been acting out a lot, and my wife and I feel like we're failing at helping him. It's affecting everything—my marriage, my work, even just enjoying life, and I'm just here because my wife insisted I come.

That sounds like a lot to carry right now—trying to support your son, maintain your marriage, and keep everything together at the same time. It must be exhausting to feel like you're being pulled in so many directions. What’s been the hardest part of this for you?

I think the hardest part is just feeling like I'm letting everyone down—my son, my wife, even my daughter. Nothing I do seems to make things better, and it’s like the harder I try, the worse it gets. It’s starting to feel like my marriage might not survive all of this, and that’s terrifying.

It sounds like you're carrying a deep sense of responsibility for everyone in your family, and feeling like you're not able to fix things is really weighing on you. The fear that this could affect your marriage adds to that already heavy load. How have you been coping with these feelings so far?

Honestly, I’m not sure I’ve really been coping. I just withdraw most of the time. I either throw myself into work, which isn’t going well because I can’t focus, or I avoid everyone at home and end up feeling guilty for it. It’s like I’m stuck in a loop.

It seems like you’ve been trying to cope in the ways you know, but it’s leaving you feeling even more disconnected and stuck in that cycle of stress and guilt. It’s a tough place to be when it feels like nothing is helping. What do you think you’d like to be different?

Honestly, I just want to feel like I’m not failing everyone. I’d like to be able to actually help my son, be present for my wife and daughter, and maybe even feel a little less overwhelmed myself. I just don’t know how to get there.

Wanting to be there for your family and feeling less overwhelmed shows how much you care about them. It sounds like your heart is in the right place, even if you're unsure of the steps to take right now. What do you think is getting in the way of feeling more present or less overwhelmed?

I feel like what's in the way is that I’m so focused on everything that’s going wrong—like my son’s behavior, my marriage feeling shaky, and just the stress piling up. It’s hard to see a clear path forward when it feels like everything is falling apart at once.

It sounds like you're caught in this constant swirl of challenges, and it’s making it really hard to see a way out. There’s so much demanding your attention that it might be hard to step back and figure out where to even start. What do you think would help you take that first small step forward?

I'm not sure, honestly. Maybe if I could figure out how to deal with my son’s behavior first, that would relieve some of the stress. But I don’t even know where to begin with that, and it feels like everything else would still be falling apart. It’s overwhelming to even think about.

It makes sense that focusing on your son seems like the natural first step since his behavior feels like such an immediate source of stress. At the same time, feeling so overwhelmed might make it tough to take any steps at all. What do you think could make it feel a bit less overwhelming or more manageable to start?

Maybe if I had a clearer direction or some guidance on how to help my son, it wouldn’t feel so impossible. Like, if someone could really understand what’s going on with him and give us specific steps to take. But even thinking about asking for that kind of help makes me anxious—I don’t want to feel like I’m failing any more than I already do.

Reaching out for guidance can feel vulnerable, especially when you’re already feeling so much pressure. It’s clear how much you want to help your son, and seeking support doesn’t mean you’re failing—it could be one of the strongest steps you take as a parent. What would make it feel easier or less intimidating to ask for that help?

Maybe if I knew where to go or who to reach out to, it’d feel less overwhelming. I don’t even know if I’m looking for a therapist for him, a parenting coach, or what. It’s all just a lot, and I’m afraid of picking the wrong thing or making things worse.

It sounds like part of what’s holding you back is not knowing exactly where to start or what kind of help would be the right fit for your family. That’s completely understandable—you want to make the best choice for everyone. Sometimes, just talking through options with someone, like a trusted professional or even your child’s school counselor or doctor, can help narrow things down. How do you feel about reaching out to someone to explore those next steps?

I guess that might be a good place to start. Maybe talking to his doctor or school counselor could give me some direction. It still feels a bit overwhelming, but if it helps us figure something out, it might be worth trying.

That sounds like a thoughtful step—connecting with someone like his doctor or school counselor could give you clearer guidance and feel a little less overwhelming than trying to figure it all out on your own. It shows how much you’re willing to try for your son and family, even when it feels difficult. How does it feel to think about taking that step?
It feels a little scary, honestly. But if it could help my son and take some of the weight off, I think it’s worth a try. Thank you for helping me figure out where to start—I appreciate it.

It’s completely normal to feel some fear when taking a step like this, but it also shows your courage and commitment to your family. Reaching out could be a meaningful way to move forward, and it’s okay to take this at your own pace. Thank you for opening up and working through this—your willingness to explore these feelings is a big step in itself. If you need support along the way, remember you’re not alone, and there are people who want to help. Take care of yourself as you move forward.
